1.0 Objective / Purpose  
The purpose of this policy is to define acceptable and unacceptable use  of ABC Organization’s 
information systems, data, devices, applications, and network resources.  
This policy ensures that all users act in a manner that:  
• Protects ABC Organization data and systems  
• Supports Zero Trust principles  
• Reduces legal, security, and operational risk  
• Aligns user behavior with established security and access control policies  
Acceptable use is a condition of access , not an entitlement.

users

Data In-Store / At -Rest (Secure Persistence) Policy  
1.0 Objective / Purpose  
The purpose of this policy is to ensure that all data stored on physical media, databases, file 
systems, backups, snapshots, and cloud storage services is protected against unauthorized 
access, disclosure, alteration, and loss , including risks arising from insider threats, 
credential compromise, misconfiguration, and physical theft . 
This policy enforces strong encryption, access controls, and key management practices  to 
ensure that stored data remains secure throughout its lifecycle, regardless of storage location or 
underlying infrastructure.  
 
2.0 Scope  
This policy applies to:  
• All data owned, processed, or managed by ABC Organization  
• All storage media and persistence layers, including:  
o On-premises servers and storage systems  
o Cloud storage services (object, block, and file stora

storage media and persistence layers, including:  
o On-premises servers and storage systems  
o Cloud storage services (object, block, and file storage)  
o Databases (relational, NoSQL, data warehouses)  
o Backup systems, snapshots, archives, and replicas  
o End-user devices where organizational data is stored  
• All employees, contractors, vendors, systems, and applications that store or manage 
ABC Organization data  
 
3.0 Definitions and Policy Requirements  
3.1 AES-256 Baseline Encryption  
All data at rest must be encrypted using strong, industry -approved cryptographic algorithms . 
• AES-256 is the minimum standard for symmetric encryption  
• Encryption must apply to:  
o Databases and file systems  
o Cloud storage buckets and containers  
o Backups, snapshots, and archival storage  
o Portable media and endpoint storage  
• Full-disk encryption is mandatory for endpoints

nd containers  
o Backups, snapshots, and archival storage  
o Portable media and endpoint storage  
• Full-disk encryption is mandatory for endpoints and servers where applicable  
Rationale:  
Encryption ensures that data remains unreadable and unusable if storage media is lost, stolen, 
or accessed without authorization.  
 
3.2 Encryption Key Management and Separation of Duties  
ABC Organization shall maintain strict separation between encrypted data  and encryption 
keys. 
• Encryption keys must be stored and managed using:  
o Hardware Security Modules (HSMs), or  
o Approved cloud -based Key Management Services (KMS)  
• Database administrators and storage administrators must not have permissions to:  
o Create, rotate, disable, or delete encryption keys  
• Key management activities must include:  
o Periodic key rotation  
o Secure key backup and recovery

3.3 Granular Data Classification and Access Enforcement  
All data must be classified and labeled according to sensitivity and business impact.  
• Minimum classification levels include:  
o Public  
o Internal  
o Confidential  
o Highly Sensitive / Regulated  
• Data classification must be:

o Enforced through access control policies  
• Access decisions must consider:  
o User identity and role  
o Device compliance and security posture  
o Contextual risk factors

Sensitive  data.”

Classification -driven controls ensure least -privilege access and regulatory alignment.  
 
3.4 Immutable Storage, Logging, and Versioning  
For critical and regulated data stores, data integrity and recoverability  must be protected.  
• Deletion and overwrite operations must be restricted  
• Storage systems should support:  
o Versioning  
o Immutable or WORM (Write Once, Read Many) storage  
• Logs and historical versions must be protected from modification or deletion  
• Ransomware protection controls must be enabled where supported  
Rationale:  
Immutability protects against data tampering, ransomware attacks, and accidental loss.

Data In-Transit (Secure Exchange) Policy  
1.0 Objective / Purpose  
The purpose of this policy is to ensure that all data transmitted between users, devices, 
applications, services, and third -party systems is protected against interception, 
unauthorized disclosure, modification, and replay attacks . 
This policy establishes mandatory encryption, authentication, and integrity controls  for data 
in transit, consistent with Zero Trust principles , where no network connection is inherently 
trusted, whether internal or external.  
 
2.0 Scope  
This policy applies to:  
• All data classified, processed, transmitted, or accessed by ABC Organization  
• All transmission paths, including:  
o Internal network communications  
o Internet-based communications  
o Cloud, hybrid, and on -premise environments  
o APIs, microservices, and service meshes  
o Remote access, third -party integratio

communications  
o Cloud, hybrid, and on -premise environments  
o APIs, microservices, and service meshes  
o Remote access, third -party integrations, and machine -to-machine 
communications  
• All users, systems, applications, devices, contractors, and vendors that transmit ABC 
Organization data  
 
3.0 Definitions and Policy Requirements  
3.1 Mandatory Mutual TLS (mTLS)  
All service -to-service and application -to-application communications must use Mutual 
Transport Layer Security (mTLS) . 
• Both client and server must authenticate each other using X.509 certificates  
• Certificates must be issued by approved internal or trusted external Certificate 
Authorities (CAs)  
• Certificate lifecycle management (issuance, rotation, revocation, expiration) must be 
enforced  
• Self-signed certificates are prohibited unless explicitly approved with documented risk 
acceptance

Rationale:  
mTLS enforces strong identity verification  and prevents impersonation, man -in-the-middle 
(MITM), and unauthorized lateral movement within the environment.  
 
3.2 Protocol Hardening and Cryptographic Standards  
ABC Organization shall enforce strong cryptographic protocols and configurations for all data in 
transit.  
The following are prohibited:  
• SSL (all versions)  
• TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1  
• FTP, Telnet, HTTP (unencrypted), and other clear -text protocols  
• Weak or deprecated cipher suites (e.g., RC4, DES, 3DES, MD5)  
Permitted standards include:  
• TLS 1.3 (preferred)  
• TLS 1.2 with AEAD cipher suites (e.g., AES -GCM, ChaCha20 -Poly1305)  
• Secure alternatives such as SFTP, HTTPS, SMTPS, and secure API gateways

• TLS 1.2 with AEAD cipher suites (e.g., AES -GCM, ChaCha20 -Poly1305)  
• Secure alternatives such as SFTP, HTTPS, SMTPS, and secure API gateways  
Rationale:  
Protocol hardening ensures resistance to cryptographic downgrade attacks and aligns with 
modern regulatory and industry best practices.  
 
3.3 Identity -Aware Proxy (IAP) and Zero Trust Access  
All access to applications and data over the network must be mediated by an Identity-Aware 
Proxy (IAP)  or equivalent Zero Trust access mechanism.  
• Access decisions must be based on:  
o Strong user identity verification  
o Device posture and compliance  
o Contextual risk signals (location, behavior, session risk)  
• Traditional VPN -based broad network access must be avoided where possible  
• Access must be limited to specific applications or services , not entire networks  
Rationale:

Rationale:  
This enforces least privilege access , reduces attack surface, and aligns with Zero Trust 
architecture by validating identity before any data transmission occurs.  
 
3.4 Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS)  
All encryption configurations for data in transit must support Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) . 
• Session keys must be ephemeral  
• Compromise of long -term private keys must not expose historical session data  
• Approved key exchange mechanisms include ECDHE or equivalent  
Rationale:  
PFS ensures long -term confidentiality even if encryption keys are compromised at a later time.  
 
3.5 Internal Network Encryption  
All internal traffic, including east -west traffic between services, containers, virtual machines, 
and microservices, must be encrypted by default.

al traffic, including east -west traffic between services, containers, virtual machines, 
and microservices, must be encrypted by default.  
• Internal networks must be treated as untrusted  
• Encryption exemptions require documented justification, compensating controls, and 
risk acceptance approval  
 
3.6 Third -Party and External Communications  
• All data exchanges with third parties must use encrypted channels  
• Third-party encryption standards must meet or exceed ABC Organization requirements  
• Contracts and SLAs must include data -in-transit security obligations

Data In-Use (Secure Processing) Policy  
1.0 Objective / Purpose  
The purpose of this policy is to ensure that data remains protected while actively processed, 
accessed, displayed, or manipulated in memory (RAM), CPU, application runtime, or user 
sessions . 
This policy addresses risks associated with memory scraping, insider misuse, screen 
capture, debugging abuse, malware, and compromised operating systems , and enforces 
Zero Trust assumptions  that even trusted hosts and users may be compromised.  
 
2.0 Scope  
This policy applies to:  
• All data owned, processed, or managed by ABC Organization  
• All processing environments, including:  
o Application runtimes and services  
o User workstations and endpoints  
o Virtual machines, containers, and serverless platforms  
o Cloud, on -premises, and hybrid environments  
• All users, applications, administrators, contractors, and

, containers, and serverless platforms  
o Cloud, on -premises, and hybrid environments  
• All users, applications, administrators, contractors, and third parties that access or 
process ABC Organization data  
 
3.0 Definitions and Policy Requirements  
3.1 Confidential Computing and Trusted Execution Environments  
For Crown Jewel , Highly Sensitive , and regulated data (e.g., PII, PHI, financial data, trade 
secrets), processing must occur within Trusted Execution Environments (TEEs)  or equivalent 
confidential computing technologies.  
• Data must remain encrypted in memory and CPU registers  
• Access to plaintext data must be restricted to authorized code only  
• Even privileged system software (OS, hypervisor) must not be able to inspect protected 
data  
• Approved technologies may include:  
o Hardware -based enclaves  
o Secure virtual enclaves  
o Cloud confidential computi

o Hardware -based enclaves  
o Secure virtual enclaves  
o Cloud confidential computing services  
Rationale:  
Confidential computing protects against advanced threats, including compromised hosts, 
privileged insider abuse, and memory scraping attacks.  
 
3.2 Dynamic Data Masking (DDM) and Contextual Redaction  
Sensitive data must be dynamically masked or redacted during active use for non -privileged 
users.  
• Masking must be applied in real time based on:  
o User role and authorization  
o Session context  
o Business need -to-know  
• Only the minimum data required to perform a task may be exposed  
• Full data visibility requires explicit approval and elevated authorization

Customer Support users may view only masked payment or identity data (e.g., XXXX -XXXX-
1234).

3.3 Endpoint Controls: Clipboard, Print, and Download Restrictions  
For Highly Sensitive  or regulated data, endpoint data loss prevention (DLP) and session 
controls must be enforced.  
• The following capabilities must be restricted or disabled where technically feasible:  
o Copy and paste  
o Print screen and screen recording  
o Local file download or export  
• Controls must be adaptive based on:  
o Data classification  
o User role  
o Device compliance and trust level  
Rationale:  
Endpoint restrictions prevent accidental or malicious data exfiltration during active use.

• Watermarks must include:  
o User identifier  
o Timestamp or session identifier  
• Attribution must be tamper -resistant  
Rationale:  
Watermarking deters misuse and enables forensic traceability in the event of data leakage.  
 
3.5 Privileged Access and Debugging Restrictions  
• Access to live production data for debugging or troubleshooting must be:

o Explicitly approved

Enterprise Encryption Policy  
1.0 Objective / Purpose  
The purpose of this policy is to establish a consistent, organization -wide cryptographic 
framework  to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and controlled use of ABC Organization 
data across its entire lifecycle.  
This policy defines approved encryption algorithms, key management principles, and 
cryptographic governance , and serves as the foundational control referenced by:  
• Data In-Transit (Secure Exchange) Policy  
• Data In-Store / At -Rest (Secure Persistence) Policy  
• Data In-Use (Secure Processing) Policy  
Encryption is a mandatory control , not an optional safeguard, and must be applied by default 
unless a formally approved exception exists.  
 
2.0 Scope  
This policy applies to:  
• All data owned, processed, transmitted, or stored by ABC Organization  
• All environments, including:  
o Cloud, on -premises

policy applies to:

o Endpoints, servers, containers, and workloads

o Data encryption  
o Key management  
o Certificate management  
o Tokenization and masking  
• All personnel, applications, services, and non -human identities involved in 
cryptographic operations

3.1 Encryption by Default  
• Encryption must be enabled by default  for all supported systems and platforms  
• Disabling encryption requires:  
o Documented business justification  
o Risk assessment  
o Formal approval  
• Encryption must be applied regardless of:  
o Network location  
o Trust zone  
o Deployment model

Encryption compensates for inevitable failures in access cont

where and when encryption must be applied .

administrative and elevated access rights are temporary, explicitly approved, task -specific, 
and fully auditable . 
This policy eliminates standing administrative access, minimizes blast radius in the event of 
compromise, and ensures that privileged access is granted only when required, for the 
shortest necessary duration, and with clearly defined intent . 
 
2.0 Scope

3.0 Definitions and Policy Requirements

Zero Trust Adaptive & Continuous Verification Policy  
1.0 Objective / Purpose  
The purpose of this policy is to eliminate implicit trust based on network location, device 
ownership, or prior authentication , and replace it with a continuous, risk -based verification 
model aligned to the principle of “Never Trust, Always Verify.”  
This policy ensures that every access request and active session is continuously evaluated  
using dynamic contextual signals, and that access is granted, limited, elevated, or revoked in 
real time  based on changing risk.  
 
2.0 Scope  
This policy applies to:  
• All employees, executives, contractors, vendors, partners, and third -party 
personnel  
• All access attempts to:  
o Applications and APIs  
o Data repositories and protected datasets  
o Infrastructure and administrative consoles  
• All environments, including:  
o Cloud, on -premises, and

Data repositories and protected datasets  
o Infrastructure and administrative consoles  
• All environments, including:  
o Cloud, on -premises, and hybrid systems  
o Corporate and remote access scenarios  
• All identity types:  
o Standard users  
o Privileged users  
o High-risk and executive identities  
 
3.0 Definitions and Policy Requirements  
3.1 Risk-Based Access Scoring and Policy Engine  
ABC Organization shall implement a centralized Policy Engine  that assigns a dynamic Trust 
Score to every access request and active session.  
• Access decisions must be made in real time using aggregated risk signals  
• Trust Scores must be recalculated continuously during the session  
• Access outcomes may include:  
o Allow  
o Allow with restrictions  
o Step-up authentication required  
o Session termination  
o Account lockdown  
Rationale:  
Static access decisions cannot account

th restrictions

o Session termination  
o Account lockdown  
Rationale:  
Static access decisions cannot account for changing threat conditions.  
 
3.2 Device Health and Endpoint Verification  
Device posture must be continuously evaluated before and during access.  
Minimum required signals include:  
• Operating system patch level and version  
• Disk encryption status  
• Active and healthy EDR / antimalware agents  
• Device ownership and management status  
• Devices failing health checks must:  
o Be denied access, or  
o Be granted restricted, read -only access where justified  
Rationale:  
Compromised or unmanaged devices represent a high -risk access vector.  
 
3.3 Network Context and Behavioral Risk Signals  
Network and behavioral context must be incorporated into risk scoring.  
Signals include, but are not limited to:  
• Geo-location

oral Risk Signals  
Network and behavioral context must be incorporated into risk scoring.  
Signals include, but are not limited to:  
• Geo-location and geo -velocity analysis  
• Known malicious IP address filtering  
• Anomalous login behavior  
• Sudden changes in network reputation or risk  
• High-risk network signals must trigger:  
o Step-up authentication, or  
o Immediate session termination  
Rationale:  
Attackers frequently exploit stolen credentials from untrusted networks.  
 
3.4 Micro -Segmentation and Protected Surfaces  
Access shall be granted only to explicitly defined protected surfaces , not to entire networks.  
• Protected surfaces may include:  
o Individual applications  
o Specific APIs  
o Sensitive datasets  
• Access must be:  
o Explicitly requested  
o Policy-evaluated  
o Limited to required resources only  
Rationale:  
Micro-segmentation limits latera

• Access must be:  
o Explicitly requested  
o Policy-evaluated  
o Limited to required resources only  
Rationale:  
Micro-segmentation limits lateral movement and reduces blast radius.  
 
3.5 Continuous Re -Authentication and Session Re -Evaluation  
Authentication is not a one -time event.  
• Active sessions must be continuously monitored for:  
o Device posture changes  
o Network context changes  
o User behavior anomalies  
• Context changes must trigger:  
o Step-up MFA, or  
o Session restriction, or  
o Immediate session termination  
Example:  
Transitioning from a trusted home network to public Wi -Fi may require re -authentication.  
Rationale:  
Risk evolves during a session, not just at login.  
 
3.6 Fallback, Lockout, and Automated Response  
When High-Risk thresholds are reached:  
• The system must automatically:  
o Lock the account or session

Automated Response  
When High-Risk thresholds are reached:  
• The system must automatically:  
o Lock the account or session  
o Revoke active tokens  
o Terminate active sessions  
• The Security Operations Center (SOC) must be notified immediately  
• Manual investigation and recovery must follow documented incident procedures  
Rationale:  
Automated response minimizes dwell time during active attacks.  
 
3.7 Privileged and High -Risk Identity Enforcement  
• Privileged and executive accounts must:  
o Be subject to stricter risk thresholds  
o Require stronger step -up authentication  
o Have lower tolerance for anomalous behavior  
• Privileged sessions must be continuously evaluated with heightened scrutiny  
 
3.8 Third -Party and External Access  
• Vendors and third parties must:  
o Be subject to the same continuous verification controls  
o Use managed or compliant devices

External Access  
• Vendors and third parties must:  
o Be subject to the same continuous verification controls  
o Use managed or compliant devices where possible  
• Risk tolerance for external identities must be lower than internal users  
 
3.9 Logging, Monitoring, and Accountability  
• All access decisions must be logged, including:  
o Trust Score  
o Risk signals evaluated  
o Access outcome  
• Logs must be:  
o Protected from tampering  
o Retained per retention policy  
• Security teams must regularly review:  
o High-risk access patterns  
o Lockouts and step -up events  
 
4.0 Enforcement
